description:
I'm surprised this place doesn't have 5 stars! This place is me and my girlfriend's favorite spot in the neighborhood. we rotate between here, Bi-rite, and salt & straw. But to be honest, we have met the owner here and that makes us want to keep coming back. He is the NICEST, and I think his son works here too. He's also nice. In fact everybody that works here is super duper nice and at the end of the day, I'd rather spend my money here than anywhere else. 

Also, AMAZING ice cream. Super rich taste, grainy, and the rotaional menu is super creative! If you ever see the spicy corn one, GET IT!!!
author: Jonah K.

description:
This place was absolutely charming! 

With an urban edge, a touch of millennial sass, and, of course, the heavenly flair of homespun-made-with-love ice cream, this place hit the mark on several levels. 

I tried the double smidge of chocolate sorbet and mint chip. My partner in crime had the double smidge of the Papanasi and Cantuccini. All were superb. We also had a fresh cup of their pour over coffee. 

Situated in a neighborhood near Golden Gate Park the atmosphere was clean and inviting. Definitely worth the drive out.
author: JoAnn Y.

description:
When I usually go to a new ice cream shop, I always try a few of the samples. These samples would always be hits or misses. Kind of like a lottery system except with not as many misses... This place was the first place where every flavor I tried tasted good (no, I did not try just one flavor).

I ended up going with a single scoop of Fresh Mint Chip ($3.98). This mint chip did not taste like the ice cream you can pick up from Safeway. It had a strong mint flavor with chocolate pieces mixed inside. It was extremely soft and I did not have to worry about my plastic spoon breaking in half like some of the other ice cream shops I have been to. 

I recommend you try this place. You'll be able to finish the ice cream using just one whole spoon!
author: Kristina M.

description:
I always root for the hometown team....but...

If your ice cream is icy and waxy I'm not a fan.

We picked up two prepacked pints ( cheesecake and bread pudding) and while the flavors were okay the texture was something I'm not a fan of. Both were icy and waxy and lacking a creamy consistency.

I still much prefer salt and straw or the gelato place up the street on 9th.

Sorry guys not for me.
author: David G.

description:
Quick Summary
- Special flavors changes on every visit (I came here twice)
- Light tasting ice cream that leaves a fresh aftertaste (no need for water to cleanse the palette) 
- Cute and unique interior with moderate seating places
- Exterior looks like it used to be a Japanese restaurant

This is my second visit, and every visit I am amazed at the delicious ice cream flavors. The colors, to my surprise, has always been more on the natural colors of white, tan, or brown (on whatever flavor I order) but that makes the ice cream special. On my first visit, I ordered a coffee flavored ice cream, and the color was just as cream colored as the bourbon vanilla ice cream. The taste was a good strong of coffee. 

There are several ice cream sizes that one can choose. The smallest size is called the smidge. This is my second visit, and I always say "I'll get the smidge," but I never do. 

One day, I want to try the five flavored ice cream size and eat like a mini feast.
author: Mito I.

description:
Ready for takeoff. 

After having dinner in the Inner Sunset, we were looking for a place to get desserts and San Francisco's Hometown Creamery was on the top of the list while checking the Yelp app. Besides, who doesn't like a flight of beer let alone ice cream? This was a genius idea sans the beer. 

It was just around the block from Irving and one block from where we parked on 9th Avenue. We crossed our fingers that there wasn't a long line on a Friday night and our wish came true. The exterior of the place had a warm and inviting look to it, and the interior was spacious yet cozy. I love the different neighborhoods represented on the painted murals located on the top walls and decorated with dark-colored wood panels that made it feel homey. 

The menu board is located on the right as you enter the place and it's seasonal and rotational, from what I could gather. But whatever flavors they had, we were ordering the flight. I was hoping they had coffee flavor, but it was not in the rotation. I told Wifey to get the Matcha Green Tea and the Asmaras Weekday Breakfast while she can chose the other three. She included the Centeotl Tribute (corn flavored ice cream named after the Maize Aztec God), Fresh Mint Tea and Schwarzwälder Eic (German chocolate). The flight also came with some waffle chips, which was a nice added touch and texture to their ice cream. 

What can I say? 

They were definitely great to look at and instagram-worthy. But one flavor that stood out the most for us among the five that we chose was the Centeolt Tribute. On their website, the flavor is described as sweet yellow maize with a smokey, sweet, and spicy Chile guajillo caramel swirled through it. If you've never had corn-flavored ice cream before, it's a familiar flavor in our culture and it's often mixed with cheese. Hey, don't knock it til' you try it.

We liked it so much, we ordered it again to-go with two scoops on a waffle. And guess what, we came back here again the next day and ordered the same thing. 

I gotta go back when the coffee flavor is in rotation and try their other flavors, which sounds very exciting as described on their website. 

But the flight is definitely the way to go so you can try five different flavors at once.
author: John G.

description:
Ice Cream: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: I'd come back!  Who doesn't love some good ice cream!

The extended review...

Ice Cream:

Mint Chocolate Chip - If you are a mint chip lover this will throw you for a loop.  The flavor is phenomenal and not like your typical mint.  It's more spearminty.

Peanut Butter Chocolate Fudge - Yum Yum.  Fairly light and not overpowering of either of the flavors which is nice!

Service:  Friendly staff!

Ambiance:  A nice place to sit around for a treat.  Seating is fairly limited though.
author: Spencer Q.

description: They have chocolate sorbet! Magically rich and fudgy chocolate sorbet at that. As someone who is somewhat lactose intolerant, at ice cream shops I am usually torn between feeling bloated/gross afterwards or limiting myself to the less enticing fruit flavors, so it's wonderful that Hometown Creamery has this creation. I appreciate the smallest "smidge" size option, especially when one is faced with the typical SF artisanal ice cream price points. The ice cream flight idea is very fun.
author: Amy G.

description: I have such a soft spot for this place. As a kid we would come to this part of the sunset all the time, so the community already makes me biased. Now - the ice cream. Their recurring peanut butter fudge flavor is so delicious. And their monster mash Halloween flavor is lovely. I only take away a star because some of the flavors are a little savory for my liking. But they're interesting and creative. The smidge size is also wonderful when you want a tiny bit of ice cream without the commitment!
author: Katie C.

description:
Delicious ice cream, friendly service, and a beautiful space ! 

Interior is lined with cool art pieces of the different districts in San Francisco! Apparently this place is the first small batch ice cream shop in SF. Pretty awesome! 

Ice cream - I got the double smidge in a cone 
With the watermelon sorbet and vanilla ice cream! 

I really enjoyed that this ice cream wasn't overly creamy or sweet, it had amazing balance and each bite left me wanting more and more! 

Also the sorbet paired so wonderfully with the vanilla ice cream! Definitely an ice cream fave!
author: Emily T.

description: The Ice cream flavours change every week.  How about Carat cake... ice cream.  You can have a single, a smig (1/2 a single) and 2 smigs (2 flavoured single).  Come by and try it.
author: Leung T.

description:
I came here knowing I would defeat the kitchen sink challenge. About one second into the challenge I knew there was no way at all I would even kind of come close. So I immediately gave up on the challenge and on any aspirations to be the next host of Man vs Food and just decided to slowly enjoy the ice cream. 

Just FYI on the challenge...they say 8 scoops of ice cream which seems totally doable (or at least doable to me) but just know that each scoop is 1.5 pounds. Ya, that's right, I said it, 1.5 pounds!! And their ice cream is suuuuuper creamy, delicious but very rich, making it even harder to eat a small baby's worth of ice cream. What I would recommend doing in the future, and probably what most people already do, just go with a group of friends and enjoy the kitchen sink together because it's fun (and yummy!).

Even though this place got the best of me, I love it. The ambiance is exactly what you'd expect from the name, it's got a nice old time-y diner/creamery feel to it. The service is really friendly. AND their non ice cream items on the menu are quite delicious, as well. I definitely think all locals should come here at least once!
author: Taline M.

description:
Take your date here! It's a small but cozy shop that features really unique, decadent ice cream flavors. Came in pretty close to closing and it had a good amount of people inside! Thankfully the staff was nice enough to let us get a flight still. I've had ice cream here before (it was a stout flavor) but wanted to come back for the flight. They rotate out flavors pretty frequently I think which is pretty cool too.

The ice cream itself tastes really high quality, and has actual chunks of ingredient in it, as weird as that sounds. One of my favorites was a Blueberry Oatmeal? ice cream and it was soooo good and had actual bits of fruit and oats. You know how Baskin Robbins' ice cream tastes pretty icy and is super homogenous? Yeah, that's the stuff to avoid. Excited to come back here when I'm in the area.
author: Nicolette E.

description: I had their coffee and Finnegan's Wake Cake flavors. Both were good. The consistency of their ice cream was a bit too icy for me though.
author: Sophia B.

description: Amazing ice cream, awesome vibe, very homey interior!! Visit for sure if you are in the area! Will be back :)
author: Amber B.

description:
3.5 stars 

The intoxicating smell of sugar permeates the air at this ice cream shop. 

At San Francisco's Hometown Creamery, choose from a petite portion called "smidge," the 5-flavor flight, or a size in the middle. There were about eight flavors to choose from when we visited, most of them creative or uncommon. 

He chose two flavors in a cone: Centeotl Tribute & Baklava. The description of the more uniquely-named one was: A Tribute to the Aztec god of Maize. Sweet yellow maize with Chile Guajillo caramel. Indeed it tasted of delicious, fresh sweet corn. The Baklava seemed more like horchata with the overwhelming taste of cinnamon & not much else. 

I chose a smidge size of Peanut Butter Chocolate  Fudge, which was lacking in chocolate or fudge. He took a taste & said it was like eating a spoonful out of a Skippy jar. I also ordered a cookie that was overloaded with butter or oil but without any distinctly sweet flavors; would not recommend.

We came here after finishing up dinner two blocks away; SFHC is a sweet option if you're in the area, pun intended, but I wouldn't go out of my way to pay them a visit.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Pretty good ice cream scoop shop. Nothing interesting here besides that they did carry 2 vegan flavors (pretty good surprisingly), and that their scoops are large.

They let me try every flavor before deciding which was kind of them.
author: Elijah B.

description: I have a major sweet tooth and naturally frequent to ice cream shops. We were in the neighborhood and figured we would give this spot a shot. I'm all for supporting local businesses and with the word Creamery in their signage, I thought this would be right up my alley. In a nutshell, the signage should substitute Creamery with Ice. The proof is always in the pudding, or ice cream, in this case. Super icy and waxy. It's all subjective, therefore if you are into this texture, then this spot could be your jam. I like my ice cream creamy or custardy. If you have a similar palate, I'd highly recommend going elsewhere (ie- Bi-Rite, Smitten or Salt & Straw).
author: Alex B.

description:
Ice cream here seemed average at best. Not wanting to eat a lot, I got a smidge cone of Madagascar vanilla (thought it tasted better than the mint). While I understand that vanilla is a basic flavor, I expected it to be better. The texture throughout was weirdly icy and I did not feel that it was worth the premium price. 

I do like the fact that they have various sizes available for various appetites. They also had good service and let us try flavors before buying.
author: Rebecca X.

description:
This ice cream store had been on my bookmarked list for the longest time and was finally in the area to try them! 

First glance of the place, loved the ambiance and decor; it was very fitting of their storefront name. 

However, onto their main products: ice cream. 

There were 8? (not that much variety) flavors, which I tried the green tea and watermelon sorbet. The green tea one was great in flavor but I wasn't the biggest fan of the tiny chewy bits of rice crispy cereal that was incorporated into it. As for the watermelon sorbet, it definitely tasted like watermelon but for some odd reason it reminded me of what children's cough syrup may have been if it was that flavor. 

I ended up choosing a single scoop of Madagascar Vanilla for $3.95, expecting it to be the original iconic ice cream of these stores. Unfortunately, it was quite disappointing. Not sure if my taste buds weren't working correctly that night, but it honestly tasted like ice cream you would buy from a grocery store... I wished it was creamier and more vanilla flavor rather than just sugar? 

Hopefully I'll be back next time to try some other flavors, but until then off to try more amazing ice cream out there in the city!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Always get the flight. ALWAYS. Don't be a wuss just do it. Love yourself and do it. Do it so you never have to choose just ONE flavor. DO it for the little cup of crushed waffle cone they provide. DO it for the gram. 

My favorite permanent flavor is the peanut butter chocolate fudge. It really doesn't get any better than their pb chocolate fudge. 

My favorite in rotation flavors are the haroset and the khao niao mamuang. 

PS. Unless you're REALLLYLLYLLYLYY into mint I wouldn't recommend that. They aren't lying when they call it FRESH mint chip. It's like straight up eating mint from the ground. Mint chip is normally my favorite ice cream but apparently I do not like fresh mint... I'm all about that fake mint extract flavor..
author: Ivy M.

description:
SF is a city with a ton of good ice cream; surprising, given how cool it is most of the year. Despite all the competition though, Hometown Creamery is right up there at the top of the heap. They rotate flavors pretty frequently and although they're not all my cup of tea, I can tell that they're very well-made all the same.

The ones I did like, though, oh man. I get a bowl, feel ecstasy, then return to reality a few blocks away with an empty paper cup and a craving for more. This has happened three times so far, I'm not even kidding. I really don't know what they do to their product, but it's been fantastic every time. Reasonably priced, too.
author: Shawn W.

description: Yum yum yum!!!! We got an ice cream flight which was so fun because you can try up to 5 flavors! All amazing! Also it is so cute in this place! The man serving us was so friendly and helpful! Can't wait to come back next time we are in town!
author: Lizzy F.

description:
Full disclosure: I don't really like ice cream. People go gaga over it but I could take it or leave it. However, after dinner at Ebisu the other night, I thought hey, my companion likes ice cream and look at Hometown, sitting right over there!

So we went. I'd go back for that mint chocolate chip, which tastes like ACTUAL MINT ladies and gentlemen. VERY VERY GOOD.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
If you live in the Bay Area, chances are you know that San Francisco is like THE place to get ice cream. Gelato, Ube, sundaes...you name it. SF has it all. 

I'm usually not a gambler, but I would definitely be willing to bet some $$ on the fact that this glorious city has over 50 different ice cream shops. And the reason why so many of them stay profitable is because each one does something most people have never experienced before. 

San Francisco's Hometown Creamery is the perfect example. Last night, I decided to take my girlfriend here for our anniversary. Despite the fact that SF has so many other insanely popular parlors (e.g. Bi-Rite, Smitten's), this place popped out because of two reasons: 1. It was the first shop in the city that made batches of ice cream from scratch ON-SITE and 2. They have a freaking 5-flavor option for ice cream (!!!). Even though Hometown Creamery wasn't the most amazing parlor of all time, I think we made the right choice. 

One look at their menu and it's clear that Hometown Creamery prioritizes quality over quantity. They serve only 10 flavors, half of which are on a rotating basis. The cool thing though is that these flavors are SO UNIQUE. When we stopped by, they had options like their Surya's Sunshine and La Vie En Rose. Totally never heard of these before. In terms of size, there are like 5-6 different choices (both in cup or waffle cone). For those who are hangry, check out the 5-flavor option (aka the Flight). If you want something other than simple scoops of ice cream, Hometown Creamery also has some drinks, confections, and even sundaes. Personally, I thought prices here were pretty reasonable. Besides the Flight (~$12), don't expect to pay more than $6-7. 

My girlfriend and I ended up ordering a proper double with Madagascar Vanilla and Fresh Mint Chip. Overall, the ice cream was pretty delicious! First off, both flavors were SO FRESH. To me, it felt like I was eating ice cream that had literally just been made. For example, the Mint Chip tasted as though someone had just crushed some mint leaves and somehow magically turned them into ice cream. Second of all, the portion size was just right. For about $6, we got two GIGANTIC scoops. My girlfriend usually loves to eat a lot of ice cream, but even she had to give me most of it. The only big downer about our experience though was the fact that the ice cream needed to be creamier. It was probably because of the freshness, but we both thought it was too light. Nevertheless, SO GOOD!

On top of the ice cream, my favorite part about Hometown Creamery was the atmosphere. The place was peaceful, music played in the background, and the decor seemed like the perfect choice for a San Francisco shop! More specifically, they had paintings of every SF neighborhood on the walls. The vibe definitely made this a nice place to eat ice cream and have fun.

Hometown Creamery is located in the beautiful Inner Sunset neighborhood on the corner of 9th and Irving. On one hand, I really love this spot because the ice cream shop is so close to Golden Gate Park and food heaven. But on the other hand, traffic and parking can be a nightmare 24/7. If you're struggling to find a parking spot, I recommend looking along Golden Gate Park. There are usually some free spaces here and there. 

With its nice ice cream and chill vibe, San Francisco's Hometown Creamery easily makes my list of best ice cream places in the city. If you're in the area and want something unique, I totally recommend this place. I give it a "Nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating. 

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
So good!! It's a perfect post-dinner dessert--not as sweet as Over the Moon, not as heavy and full as Humphry Slocombe. Of course, this ranges from flavor to flavor, the Unity (New York Cheesecake) was definitely the richest out of the three we picked. My favorite was the Strawberry Balsamic, the balsamic adds a nice mellowness to an otherwise fresh flavor. For the non-diary folks, they had at least two sorbet options when I went: chocolate and a fruity one.

It was still pretty popping at 9 PM on a Sunday night, but with only 8 flavors to choose from the line moves fairly quickly. Definitely adding this into my ice cream rotation, and am excited to try new flavors.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I like the layout of this venue and also the options they have.

In particular I like the :
a) smidge option
b) flight option

I think all ice cream venues should have smaller taste testing options like this venue does.

I ended up going with the :
Madgascar Vanilla 
Fresh Mint Chip 

I thought they were pretty good here and have this place in the middle of the pack of my rankings below.  Very friendly service and super close to some other popular dining places so a good options for dessert if you're nearby.

So many good ice cream spots in the city. Here is my ranking but they are all pretty darn good.

Who doesn't love Chocolate and Ice Cream? (If you're raising your hand you can stop here ) 

I like making lists what can I say. I have lists for Ramen, Steakhouse/Brazilian , Milk Tea, Egg Tarts, Chicken & Waffles (super random list right). Give my profile a follow if you like them. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod's San Francisco Chocolate and Ice Cream shop Rankings: 
1 Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous
2 Marco Polo Gelato
3 Dandelion Chocolate
4 Polly Ann Ice Cream
5 salt and straw
6 Chocolate Covered
7 Smitten Ice Cream
8 Teuscher Chocolate 
9 Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream
10 Over the Moon
11 The Ice Cream Bar
12 Coletta Gelato
13 Cako Creamery
14 Bi-Rite Creamery
15 San Francisco's Hometown Creamery 
16 Miyako Old Fashioned Ice Cream
17 Mitchells Ice cream
18 St. Francis Fountain
19 Z Cioccolato
20 Joe's Ice Cream
21 Christopher Elbow Artisanal Chocolate
22 The Baked Bear- Custom Ice Cream Sandwiches
23 Recchiuti Confections 
24 Poco Dolce Chocolates
author: Rod M.

description:
Very delicious, unique flavors! 
All of the flavors sounded amazing so I love how they had the option for a flight. You get five flavors of your choice served in shot glasses held in a wooden box. So cute! I was with a friend and we could hardly finish! 

I truly enjoyed each flavor. 
My favorites in order:

1. Dark chocolate sorbet: very rich dark chocolate flavor. Texture was sooo silky and smooth. You must realllllly love chocolate to enjoy this one.
2. Horchata: cinnamon-y sweet also flavored with almond. Wasn't what I expected, but still delicious.
3. Stout of the Union: before I knew what it was, I guessed it was made with cognac lol the beer wasn't overpowering and I loved the brownie chunks.
4. Mint chocolate chip: not the typical mint ice cream flavor you find in your store bought ice cream. Very fresh mint taste with the crunch of chocolate chunks.
5. Honey chamomile ginger sorbet: it was hard to enjoy this one because all the sweet ice creams we had made this extremely sour. When I guessed what this one was I thought lemonade. I could taste the chamomile but not so much ginger. The texture was a bit icey. Would be so refreshing on a hot day!

They serve the flight with a cup of waffle cone shards! 

Definitely will be coming back.
author: Mary R.

description: Honest to god some of the best ice cream I've ever had. No pictures because I ate it that fast! God bless this establishment.
author: Emily G.

description:
We stumbled upon the SF Hometown Creamery after having lunch at Nopalito and I was in the mood for ice cream. The gentleman working was very friendly and asked if I would like a sample, Of course! I tried the Mint Chocolate Chip and holy cow it tasted like fresh mint with hints of chocolate throughout. I was super impressed and ordered a single!
It was simply delicious, I've never had mint choco chip ice cream that tasted so real!

It looks like they have daily special flavors each day and they all sounded delicious and unique! 
The location is really cool, and I had no idea there was so much history here, I can't wait to visit again!
author: Larissa S.

description:
SFHC lives up to the hype!

It's cute on the inside and has a lot of really charming quirks, like the map of the world where you can put a pin on your own hometown.

The flavors are unique and all delicious in so many different ways! First of all, you can do an ice cream flight which I've never seen before but is a huge plus! I love being able to try several different kinds without committing to getting a huge scoop. So I tried the chocolate peanut butter fudge, which is good even if you're not a chocoholic but if you are, it's dangerously addictive. The caipirinha is intense but does justice to its namesake cocktail! I also tried the bread pudding ice cream, which was okay but not my favorite. It was sweet and tasted a little like maple, which was great, but the chunks of bread pudding had a weird texture. The fruity cheesecake flavor, Unity, was great and the berries were very apparent in the ice cream, which was refreshing. Lastly, I tried the strawberry balsamic flavor which was AMAZING. Think: sweet strawberry yogurt in ice cream form. You also get pieces of cone with the flight so that you can dip, and the cone has a great cinnamon-y flavor to it.

I can't wait to come back and try the other flavors SFHC makes!
author: Claire C.

description:
Yum! 

What I tried:
*Stout - unique and delicious 
*Peanut butter - bf compared it to a peanut butter cup 

Overall thoughts:
*Service was great, worker asked us if we wanted to sample 
*nice ambiance and place to sit down
*unique flavors 
*seems like flavors get changed occasionally 
*will be coming back
author: Sarah W.

description:
I came across this spot as I was walking to lunch at the sushi restaurant across the street, Ebisu and decided to try it out after lunch. 

This place has apparently been around for a long time and has a very home-y feeling inside. 

There were various flavors to choose from - whether you wanted one of their classic flavors such as madagascar vanilla, mint chip, chocolate sorbet, or one of their specialty flavors which are only around for a limited time. 

We were really excited about the specialty flavors so we tried a few - Early grey and lavender and biscotti. I was actually a bit disappointed with the specialty flavors as I felt like they had a bit too much flavor. The earl grey one had too much lavendar flavor, and the biscotti had too much anise flavor in my opinion. 

We ended up sticking with the basic classic flavors - madagascar vanilla and mint chocolate chip. Both were delicious and we topped it with waffle bits (which were much larger than bits, but rather waffle pieces). 

I would potentially come back if I happen to be in the area, but I would stick with the classic flavors. If you're feeling adventurous, you can sample some of the other flavors!
author: Claire W.

description:
This is a lovely small ice creamery business. After walking through 9th St. and shopping, this store is a good place to stop and get refreshed with homemade ice cream--in small batches. 

We had a "smidge" size of La Vie en Rose. WOW, was there the rose flavor and little bits of edible rose petals. It was truly a unique flavor. The place is small, clean, and quiet. ( I love those kinds of places where you can have an intimate conversation and share food.)
 
As others have stated, parking is very tricky around this neighborhood, but it's well worth the walk to come here.
author: Cleo C.

description:
Cute little ice cream shop.  Looks old school, but has small batch flavors that are on par with new wave ice cream shops like Humphrey Slocombe.

Ice Cream Sandwich w/ French Roast Coffee: This was delicious!  The ice cream tasted like a sweetened iced latte in ice cream form.  It wasn't like that dark heavy brew flavor some places have for their coffee ice cream.  Light and refreshing!  The sandwich part involved two chocolate chip cookies that had just the right balance of firmness and chewiness to support an ice cream sandwich.  I really appreciate that they scooped it to order so the ice cream isn't hard like a hockey puck (as can be the case with pre-made ice cream sandwiches).
author: Adam B.

description:
Salt & Straw, Bi-rite, Humphrey Slocombe, Tara's, Three Twins, Smitten, Ghirardelli, Over the Moon.....I've made my rounds and love this place the most for the most refreshing ice cream.

I'm not so much a super creamy ice cream type, so take that into account....but this spot gives you a rich ice cream taste with a cool and a little bit icier finish that makes you feel like you've cleansed your palate instead of dropped a brick of cream into your stomach.

Extremely fresh ingredients, and they're the first site in SF to make their own ice cream from scratch to final product.  Their mint chip is to die for, since they create its base by infusing 10lbs of spearmint into the cream like you would with tea
author: Mon T.

description: Do yourself a favor and make this your new ice cream spot. Their flavors are DELICIOUS and not the same flavors your find in every other ice cream spot. The mint chip is seriously out of this world, next level - it tastes more minty than actual mint (and that's coming from someone who isn't usually into mint ice cream). Love love LOVE!!!
author: Molly G.

description:
the employees here are super nice. I went on a saturday, it wasnt as packed as i see in some pictures. They have a variety of flavors. The price for the scoop is a bit not proportional. i say this because the scoop is a bit tiny, its smaller than my fist.

What is that!! not sure if anyone ever heard of this saying, but "people have a separate stomach just for desert." which basically means we can eat alot until you stomach is full, but you will always have room for desert! :) :)
author: Bonnie C.

description:
Ice cream lover here! Let me just say, I've experienced better.

Atmosphere is great, seating is not (limited). I was trying to reserve 2 spots as my friends were waiting in line to order. People were rude and trying to take the seats away. Also, the line doesn't move fast. I waited, for what felt like an eternity, for my friends to get to the front of the line (to order).

The ice cream flavors were very strong and a little strange for my taste. You know it's not the best when you only focus on eating vanilla. Don't get me wrong, vanilla is great but I usually like a variety; however, in this case, the variety was not my cup of tea. 

My least favorite: fresh mint chip. It's definitely "fresh". I usually enjoy flavors like lavender, mint, tamarind, cinnamon, etc. However, the taste was so strong I felt like I was eating raw herbs in ice cream. I would say it tasted like grass but I never had grass...so....I can't really make an assumption. Also didn't like the overpowering taste of PB Chocolate Fudge.

Overall, had a disappointing experience. And will probably not return.
author: Ida H.

description:
Some of friends are big fans of this place so I've come here a few times. Ever since.I tried holy gelato, I haven't been back once. 

It's a small family bussiness and they make small batch ice cream, which means the flavors change every now and then and jt may not come back until a year later.

I've had their stawberry a few months and it's the only one I liked. I also had green tea, really bitter and vanilla, tastes really plain. 

Overall, if you like your ice cream sweet and creamy, this is not the place for you
author: Laura S.

description: The ice cream flight is so great bc it lets you try so many different flavors. The sticky rice ice cream and smores ice cream were sooooo good! I'll definitely be back.
author: Ash S.

description:
This place is awesome! The cutest little date spot with a nice, welcoming vibe located in SF's sunset district. 

Food: They have the coolest ice cream flavors and change them up often. I went during the week of the Indian festival, Diwali so they had a special - the gajjar ka halwa (carrot dessert), which was delicious! The ice cream flight is perfect if you want to try a few of the flavors, but I'll admit, the portion seemed too large for two people to share. I think it would be perfect for 3-4 people. They also use mini metal spoons (yay recycling!) for the samples. 

Atmosphere: Very cute and quaint! They have a map on the wall where customers can pin their hometowns - such an adorable touch to the ice cream parlor. 

Staff: super kind and patient. They were all so friendly especially with the little kids who wanted to try practically every flavor haha. 

Price: very affordable and worth it! The ice cream flight was about ~$12 and worth every dollar, especially since you get a variety of flavors (yummmm). 

Will I be back? I was visiting the area so don't know when I'd be back, but their unique flavors would definitely pull me in again if I'm around!
author: Tahira R.

description:
I finally got to try out this place and it did not disappoint! 

My boyfriend said he heard from a coworker that the strawberry balsamic ice cream was really good. I sampled that one and the mint chip. The mint was VERY MINTY. I ended up getting a scoop of the strawberry balsamic. OOH IT WAS TASTY! Very fruity and the balsamic wasn't overpowering at all. I couldn't really taste the balsamic in the ice cream, when I was expecting it to have a strong flavor. 

Normally, my boyfriend tends to just take bites of my ice cream, but since he enjoyed the strawberry balsamic so much himself, he ordered himself a scoop too. 

Great little ice cream spot and I will definitely have to come back here to try a flight of many ice creams. :)
author: Heather I.

description:
We stopped here after our visit to the Musuem of Ice Cream (ice cream overload, I know! YOLO!)

Rave reviews about the flight (5 flavors, $11.95), so we ordered one.

Flavors: Carrot Cake, Lemon, chocolate, peanut butter, and vanilla. 

The flavors were absolutely delightful, and the crushed waffle cone side made it even better. 

Street parking + nearby garages. 

Customer service: 4 stars 
Ambience: 4 stars 
Variety and flavors: 5 stars
author: Tushar S.

description: Love the casual ambience but I'm giving it a 3 because the quality of the ice cream itself is just alright compared to places like Salt and Straw and Humphrey Slocombe. The ice cream feels airy and tastes bland in comparison to other places in SF with similar price points. Head over to bi rite, salt and straw, or Humphrey Slocombe for better tasting ice cream; do come over once for a chill sitting tho, the peeps here are nice :)
author: Leo W.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday with my friend after eating At lemonade, right next door. We were craving ice cream and we saw this place and decided to walk in. The storefront has a lot of San Francisco tourist areas all over it. They also have an explanation on the wall that they are the first Ice cream store in San Francisco to serve Home made ice cream. 
Interior rate 4/5
They don't have that many flavors I think only 7-8 flavors. I ordered the strawberry balsamic which was very delicious, the balsamic adds something to the strawberry that makes it unique! I ordered the single scoop in a cup and it costs $3.95. My friend ordered the berry cheesecake flavor in a cup as well. She said it was very delicious and not too sweet or overwhelming. They also rotate their flavors daily, which gives people a chance to try different flavors!
Food rate 4/5
The service was just mediocre, the guy who helped us wasn't extremely friendly or welcoming and seemed annoyed at us for trying the flavors. 
Service rate 3/5
Overall I would probably come back again to try some other flavors!
author: Carissa C.

description:
I wouldn't go so far as to call myself an ice cream connoisseur, but seeing chocolate sorbet on Hometown Creamery's outdoor flavor chalkboard had me doing a double take. Sorbet makes me think of fruit, and while college me joked that wine helped me get my daily serving of fruit, chocolate would surely be a stretch.

But because I am a sucker for anything chocolate, I decided to give the chocolate sorbet flavor a try. Heads up in advance: there's a daily rotating menu of flavors and the online menus aren't always up-to-date. That's something to keep in mind if you're picky when it comes to ice cream, but I believe there might be a few select flavors, such as the chocolate sorbet, that are a permanent fixture on the menu. SFHC is a small local business -- you can tell by the cozy, rustic decor, original art on the walls, and the fact that their ice cream is made by scratch on-site.

Not knowing what to expect from the chocolate sorbet, I was pleasantly surprised by its richness. (Don't get this if you're not a fan of dark chocolate.) The Yelp reviewer who described the flavor as a brownie in sorbet form hit the nail right on the head. Yet the chocolate sorbet flavor wasn't special enough to warrant paying $3.95 for a single scoop -- I wish I had gotten the slightly smaller smidge (Hometown Creamery's smallest scoop). If anything, know that you'll get your money's worth with the single scoop if you pick the right flavor (or really, come on the right day). The homemade waffle cone was delicious and had a subtle spice kick to it, which complemented the ice cream well.
author: Amy C.

description:
Tried this place last night based on good reviews from yelp!

Got the flight and tried aztec chocolate, mint chocolate chip, chocolate sorbet, Madagascar vanilla, and peanut butter chocolate fudge. We weren't going to get the chocolate sorbet but we had tried a flavor (began with a C.... Some Italian name?....) and weren't fans of it.

Overall, good ice cream and favorites were peanut butter chocolate fudge and either one of the chocolate ones. The mint one was interesting, very minty... Not your typical mint chocolate chip...

Docking one star for lack of variety... About 9 flavors to choose from but really only 7 (bc we didn't like carrotcake or lemon) to make our flight of 5 flavor...
author: Cal C.

description:
Limited but unique flavors. Unfortunately, none to my liking. But it might be just right for others!

Pros:
+ Local business
+ Cute interior with paintings of the different districts

Cons:
- Small selection of flavors
- Don't recall anything chocolatey when I came in on Monday, 11/20/2017
- Consistency/flavor was just not there for the Madagascar Vanilla

They didn't have flavors that really jumped out at me and made me want to try them, so I went with the Madagascar Vanilla, which was dismal. There wasn't much flavor, compared to the Double Fold Vanilla at Salt and Straw (which is amazing!). Yes, many call Vanilla basic, but to each their own.

Gave it a second chance. Will not be returning.
author: Fanny W.

description:
Awesome.  As expected after reading Yelp.  

What we like ...
- the five ice cream combo dish (forgot their name).   It's better than individual cones because it's great to share among friends
- we love the "peanut butter chocolate fudge" flavor
- the waffle cone (I think that it's made at the store)

What can be better ...
- put in more tables or chairs so groups can share the five ice cream combo
author: Mike Y.

description:
This place is located near Golden Gate Park, somewhere in between there and San Tung. We decided to stop by as a treat and ended up getting the 5 flavor flight for about $12. We tried pumpkin cheesecake, chocolate, green tea, some sort of apple pie, and some sort of Thai Mango sticky rice flavor.

The flavors overall were just okay. They supposedly make it in small batches and locally, but the flavor didn't really taste all that great. The chocolate was rich and the pumpkin cheesecake tasted pretty good, but the other flavors fell short.

The Match Green Tea felt kind of bland in places, the apple pie felt like it was lacking something and had too much apple at points, and the thai mango flavor was not pleasant. It didn't really have a dairy taste and felt kind of like I was eating frozen coconut milk with pieces of mango inside, but that weren't really well formed.

I'd probably pass on this place in the future, but the flights are fun though if you have a couple people and want to try a few different flavors. It also comes with crushed up pieces of cone which is kind of nice (they make that fresh too, but it didn't taste that great unfortunately).
author: Tyler T.

description:
service was great!

there was plenty of seating! 

the ice cream was very airy and icy, not the kind of texture i was expecting for an artisan ice cream place. maybe it's just not my jam.
author: Marjo M.

description:
I've done the whole Humphrey Slocombe, Garden Creamery, Salt & Straw, etc. rounds of gourmet ice creams. I have to say that SF's Hometown ranks very highly up there among the best of the best. 

We came here after eating nearby at San Tung (2), and decided to get a flight because we are rarely in the Sunset neighborhood. The flavors I got (from L to R in the photo) were as follows:

-Big Heart: bourbon w/ homemade toffee caramel, and pound cake (proceeds went to hurricane relief)
-Apples and honey (Rosh Hashannah-themed)
-Horchata
-Peanut butter chocolate fudge
-Caipirinha sorbet: Brazilian sugar and lime cocktail

We thought all of these were really good - very rich, creamy, and distinctly flavored. The two standouts for me were the last two, Caipirinha and peanut butter chocolate fudge. I thought the Caipirnha was a great palate cleanser, and almost like those frozen Minute Maid lemonades you get at theme parks/ball games. The peanut butter chocolate fudge was just like a Reese's peanut butter cup. 

I also have to give the guy who was making our flight a shout-out. He was a younger guy with brown hair who put more care into crafting each scoop of ice cream than I usually do with my own personal appearance most days. I really appreciated the artistry he was employing while preparing our scoops for us.
author: Jenny D.

description:
Hands down, probably one of the best ice cream places in SF! 
We got the flight with mint chocolate chip, strawberry balsamic, Chocoberry cheesecake, French roasted coffee, and honey mango sorbet. We literally couldn't pick a favorite because they were all soooooo good. Come here! You won't be disappointed.
author: Mary C.

description:
Came here to try their famous ice cream flight...no regrets!! You get five flavors for around $13 - my cousin and I got the Rose, Chocolate, Vanilla, Strawberry Balsamic, and something else I forget. Definitely recommend the chocolate and strawberry!

We came here after visiting the De Young Museum; if you're in the area of Golden Gate Park, it's a great little place to get ice cream. The two workers who served us were super helpful (and rather attractive), and after searching them up online, I found out they were two brothers who owned the shop!

Coming back soon to try their other flavors!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
Flight costs 11.95 which is perfect for sharing with 3-4 friends where the price ends up being not bad :), plus u get to have lots of flavors. 
My personal favorites are the tea time which combines 2 of my favorite ice cream flavors: earl grey and lavender yumm, and also fresh mint chip which basically is super freshly minty reminds me of Philz without the coffee haha. We also tried the apple and honey which was okay, I'm not a huge apple pie person so I wasn't a huge fan. And the pear sorbet kind of tasted like mushy pear applesauce to me, so I wasn't that into it but my friends enjoyed it. TMI note my burps after were minty fresh yummy LOL. They also give a cup of crushed cones which was a yummy touch as well. 
Definitely recommend the flight if you plan to share with friends :)!
author: Nina W.

description: Their vegan ice cream is amazing! It's so, so, so good. It's also super chocolatey, and soft and creamy, unlike most vegan ice cream it's not icy. We also tried the mint chocolate chip ice cream, and it tastes like actual mint, not the store bought kind you can usually get. Definitely would recommend San Francisco's Hometown Creamery.
author: Ayla T.

description:
Can't fathom how it took me so long to finally try this spot!! I somehow did not realize it was so conveniently located outside Golden Gate park! 

There is street parking, available on a first come first served basis, as per usual SF. We were able to snag a spot a block away on an early Sunday evening. 

The parlor clearly displays their 'hometown ' pride with unique artwork representing the various city neighborhoods. It's clean, has a decent amount of seating available, and an easily accessible gender neutral restroom. 

I was so excited seeing their sign of flavors for the day! However, knowing that they serve flights (ZOMG!!) I had hoped for a greater quantity of total flavors. NBD. Quality over quantity 

Loved that they offer multiple sizing choices with the smidge and double smidge options! It was perfect for me since I always like to split scoops in order to maximize on my trip to flavortown without OD'ing on ice cream. I opted for a double smidge in a waffle cone with the banoffee and the roasted black sesame with white miso caramel (double ZOMG!). The banoffee ice cream had a genuine banana flavor with large chunks of shortbread (impressively large chunks) and delicious dark chocolate toffee pieces, it was a great balance of salty and sweet. I am a moth drawn to the flame whenever I encounter black sesame, needless to say I've tried many versions!! However, this one really stood out because of the white miso caramel. It added definite sweetness but was oh so miso-y. Bravo!

The waffle cone was bomb. Clearly fresh, a little sugary. I will say the ice cream seemed to melt rather rapidly. So I ended up eating it a lot quicker than I'd prefer. This creamery has got the A flavor game for sure but the texture is not on the same level of smooth creaminess as say Garden. 

Overall, truly delicious and well worth a stop if you're in the area. Those bourbon maple pecan bars looked amazing and they have a house cider. Will have to stop by again to try more!
author: Megan A.

description:
Got the Fresh Mint Chip and chocolate chip cookies, and really wasn't impressed. 

The cookie was fine, texture was good, but it wasn't that flavorful. The best chocolate chip cookies to me are both sweet from the sugar and a little salty from the butter, but these weren't either, they were just kinda bland and boring. 

The ice cream was actually bad, I think-- it was icey rather than creamy, it didn't particularly taste like mint, it had a weird aftertaste, and the chocolate bits were chalky almost like how chocolate gets when it expires. 

I'm a little confused by this order, so I might try them one more time but I won't be ordering either of these items again.
author: Virginia J.

description:
[Out-of-Town-Review]

A flight of ice cream is WAY better than a flight of beer...

...any day! 

If you don't mind fighting to find a spot to park, then I'd try this spot. Or be like us and have your driver just drive around while you wait in line and order the goodness that is SFHC!

On the day we were there, the options were a little more advanced for a nine-year old. She did end up with the chocolate gelato, but all the options were not really her ideal ice cream treat.

As for us adults, this place was awesome. Even for those adults on the pickier side, there was still something we could get down with. I ended up trying most of them as a newbie. And yes, this place, like all others in SF, sample their ice creams with real life, miniature spoons.

I enjoyed the more exotic (or less traditional) flavors such as Roasted Black Sesame, Abacate (avocado), and Pluot sorbet. However, I stuck with something I'd usually order, the French Roast Coffee. It was really light in color, but packed a deliciously strong coffee flavor that was amazing!

I absolutely love that they offer a 'smidge' size. Instead of calling it kids size or making that their single scoop, they found a better solution. I really wanted to try the flight of ice cream, because who wouldn't and because it was priced really well!

Sadly, they were just making the freshly baked waffle cones for single scoops, so I couldn't get one. I ended up with a single scoop in a cup with a 'smidge' cone on top. As I walked out of the store I jammed the entire scoop into the 'smidge' cone and threw away the cup. It got a little messy, but that's what napkins are for!

After you order your ice cream, you walk past a little pastry case, which is nothing fancy at all. On top, they had fresh baked chocolate chip cookies and on the bottom, they had Bourbon Blondes (or something like that

Due to the location, I'm not sure this would be considered one of my favorite ice cream spots in SF. I do appreciate that they were the first to do small batch ice cream and even pasteurize in-house, but it's kind a nightmare to get too.

Their 'Farm to Cone' movement is ideal, but their parking is NOT!
author: Steph G.

description: Getting the flight is honestly the best way to go! We got chocolate sorbet, peanut butter chocolate fudge, watermelon, matcha green tea, and Schwarzwälder Eic which is Black Forest cake ice cream. Each flavor was unique, rich, and most of all, delicious! Each flight also comes with a cup of waffle cone bits. Definitely planning on dropping by again!
author: Erin D.

description:
It's both a blessing and a curse that this creamery is so close to my house. It's so freakin good and every time I pass by, I fight the urge to make a visit. 

The Ice cream really does taste authentic and rich with flavor. It's that type of ice cream that splits like butter when you run your spoon through it, it's incredible. 

Most importantly, DON'T FORGET ABOUT THE COOKIES. My goodness, you heat up one (Often two) of these bad boys, top it off with your favorite flavor of their ice cream and you'll find yourself at the doorsteps of heaven. 

Great service as well, i'd highly recommend!
author: Quinton B.

description:
I like the unique flavors here. They have different flavors such as Strawberry Balsamic and Lavender Thyme which I really like. Not a big fan of the chocolate sorbet however. 

I would totally try their flights if it's your first time there or would love to share with a friend to get many different flavors. Though, they don't offer anything more than 3 scoops to go. But I definitely asked for 4 scoops and they were able to accommodate but be mindful that the container was too small for 4 scoops so you'll have to eat  fast before they all melt.
author: Dream-Suphada L.

description:
This hometown creamy is different from other ice cream places throughout SF! They offer unique flavors that I normally wouldn't get so it was nice to venture out and get something different for once :) 

When you walk in, you'll be greeted by the workers here and they're super friendly! They'll recommend you certain ice cream flavors and offer samples! There's a lot of seating here that's not the problem. The problem is finding parking! You'll be spending about 10-20 minutes finding parking.

This place is worth trying! Definitely get it in the waffle cone which I believe they make it fresh!
author: Katty X.

description: I came here with my fiancé to check out what the rave was about this place. It's a very cute place to enjoy some delicious ice cream. We ended up getting the ice cream flight and it comes with 5 scoops of different flavors of ice cream and a side of waffle cone bits. I really loved this place and had a good time with my fiancé.
author: Neloffer E.

description:
OMG! Whoh!  This place has special varieties of interesting ice cream flavors.  Totally love the carrot cake and non dairy chocolate flavors!  Both smooth and creamy!

My only complaint is the small scoop!  One scoop on a fresh  made waffle cone is 4 dollars.  The special with 5 scoops is 12 dollars.  I would stay with one favorite flavor so I could be happy with my selection. People working here are very nice!  VIP service when you come here!   They will allow you to taste and try out different flavors.  They all are awesome.  You just have to decide what you will like more!  

You can see the clean room where the ice cream is made.  I like the cute deco and pretty murals on the wall!  its 's the locally made ice cream store in the neighborhood near my school, UCSF.  I love this part of SF!

Parking around here is super tough.  If you are willing to park a few blocks away, and with patience, you will get a spot!

I scream, you scream, we all scream for Ice Cream!
author: Ivory B.

description:
Nice home-made ice cream. More on the icy side, but definitely denser than ice cream at other shops. The flavors are vivid and lays on the palette well. 

We ordered the flight of their flavors on rotation - those new flavors that will be gone in a short while. This is a great way to sample many flavors, served in, what else, shot glasses! 

My only complaint is that the unisex restroom was a mess. Paper towels piling up outside the small garbage pail. Granted, the store was very busy, but it should be regularly checked for cleanliness. On the positive side, once I notified one of the workers, the restroom was promptly cleaned. 

I now want to try their standard flavors!
author: Vernon M.

description:
this ice cream place is good! Worth a try. But, was disappointed in the flavors. The earl grey was almost there! It just needed a liiiitle more wha-bam. The carrot cake was tasty! Madagascar vanilla fell flat. The flight is a creative and neat way to try a ton of flavors!! That was awesome! 

Water rating: 7/10.
author: Amanda P.

description:
I'm not going to give this one much thought.  Flavor  was good but they were very limited in flavors as a small batch ice cream maker.  Like other San Francisco ice cream makers, maybe only half the flavors appealed to my taste so I went with a chocolate chip.  

What I did not like was the chaos line where people cut in, the lng wait by indecisive people who wanted to taste 6 flavors and still couldn't decide.  Lastly and most importantly it is super-expensive for the mini-scoops they provide.  There are better deals nearby for a cold dessert treat.
author: Erik H.

description: Get the flight!! It was a perfect treat to share with someone. If you want to sample a flavor (they change regularly), just ask for a sample. Ample seating inside and service was really friendly. The most unique flavor was the white chocolate rose with bits of white chocolate mixed inside. Highly recommended!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Expect a line but trust me, it's totally worth it! We loved being able to try different ice creams with the 5 scoop flight. You can really tell they have passion for their craft.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
Line was not too long on the Friday night we went. However, it was still very crowded for the night inside. Thankfully we found a table quickly. 

Try all the flavors first and decide. An honest good idea is the flight. Although it's not the cheapest, but split amongst five or six people, it's a pretty good idea. Especially because none of us really wanted that much ice cream, just something sweet to compliment dinner. 

We just got all the rotational flavors for or flight of five.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Summary: Over-priced ice cream with exotic names that fall short to expectations. 

This is a cute ice cream shop on 9th and Irving in Inner Sunset, where a lot of other nice shops and restaurants are located. 

They have a number of unique flavors (strawberry balsamic, unity (NYC cheesecake with corn bread bits/chunks), hibiscus lemon sorbet, etc.) so a group of us felt encouraged to check this place out. I sampled the strawberry balsamic and thought it was pretty bland. I didn't taste any hint of balsamic in it-- it seemed like unsweetened light, strawberry ice cream. 

I got two smidges of Unity and hibiscus lime ($4.50). Unity was pretty tasty, although not well-mixed. I had a large nob of purple-colored cornbread in mine, which size-able relative to the smidge size I got. The hibiscus wayyyy too tangy. I couldn't taste anything in this except the lime. The color was startlingly purple, so the whole smidge was just a wacky experience.
author: Julia Y.

description: Seriously good artisan ice cream. I can't get over how delicious their earl grey/lavender flavor ice cream was. I also tried their Aztec chocolate and that had the perfect amount of spice. The great thing is that they offer a variety of sizes so you don't have to over indulge and commit to a giant scoop of ice cream. You can either get their little size and or even order their ice cream flight. The ice cream was creamy and flavors were bold and strong. The way I like it. The smallest scoops start at less than 3 dollars. They also have a rotating selection of sorbets. Great date spot.
author: Diane T.

description:
First impression: The decor was rustic and homey--everything was wood and looked hand painted. There were string lights up on the windows, and it made the whole interior feel so warm. Also, there was a cool map where people could place tacks on where they were from! Very cute.

What I Ordered:

-The Flight (4/5, $11.95): The flavors we ordered from left to right are Vanilla Madasgacar, Alfajores, Hibiscus Sorbet, Cookies and Cream, and Rocky Road. They were all delicious! One flavor that really stuck out was the hibiscus--it was extremely refreshing. The Vanilla was also amazingly rich! It was also a lot more ice cream than I was anticipating, which was great. Also very cute and useful that you get waffle cone bits with the flight! They tasted great when dipped in the ice cream. I really like the concept of the ice cream flights--you get a decent amount of ice cream, plus you get to try five different flavors. The sorbet was a little bit icy, but very flavorful. 

Customer Service: The cashier up front was very sweet, giving us lots of samples with a smile, until we said that we'd like to order a flight. Her smile immediately dropped from her face and she looked vaguely annoyed that she'd have to arrange another flight. I get that it takes a lot of precision, but it is their signature item so I feel like our request shouldn't have been out of the ordinary. To be fair, it was late, and she might have had an off day, so I understand, but it was still a little bit off putting and made me uncomfortable. (-1 star)

All in all, the ice cream here is great! Honestly, besides the flight, I don't really see much that differentiates this creamery from the rest of the San Francisco ice cream shops (and there are many haha). It is definitely in a convenient spot though--if you're grabbing food nearby on Irving Street, you should swing by for dessert!
author: Stephanie N.

description: We had two chocolate chip cookies and a pecan bar.  Ice Cream looked scrumptious but too cold to eat.  So the cookies were nothing special chocolate wasn't even very noticeable.  But, the pecan bar was something to be very pleased with.  My husband even said he wished we had gotten a second one even though he doesn't like Pecan Pie or anything like it.  Would love the recipe as we aren't in San Francisco very often.
author: Laura Y.

description: Nice, strong flavors and good pricing for a small treat! We stopped in after hanging out in Golden Gate Park and tried four flavors: sesame/miso (tasted like a Halvah bar), strawberry/balsamic (the only "icy" texture, as other reviewers have sometimes commented, but the flavor was super fresh), coffee (tasted like a strong latte, not very sweet), and peanut butter fudge (the one we ultimately got, and we really loved the flavor and smoothness of the fudge swirl). Compared to getting $5 soft serve in the park, we found the $2.50 for the smallest size of ice cream was quite reasonable, and we also loved the art on the walls showcasing different San Francisco neighborhoods. In terms of flavors, it ranks right up there with other ice cream places!
author: Vijay N.

description:
I stopped in here because it said ice cream and was on my way...and I'm a huge snob with my carb calories and researched their principles. 

Homemade ice cream: check
Farm to table: check 
Good ingredients: check

So they have this Fresh Mint Ghirardelli Chip. I'm mildly skeptical but hopeful. Okay, it totally checks the fresh mint box. I swear I felt like I'd been eating mint out of the yard for an hour after. Sadly, cold, the Ghirardelli chips are mealy. Other chocolates can hold up better.

I'm still giving them 5 stars for the acknowledgement of the need for a dainty, single scoop of ice cream they call a "smidge." $2.50 and just enough to taste, enjoy, and not break the calorie bank. 

This place is so out of my way normally, but for that mint? It is a destination.
author: Mari H.

description:
I finally got it!  Walked by after dinner nearby and saw that the ice cream was there!!

I went to the fridge and after looking for a minute, the ice cream chef asked if I couldn't find what I was looking for and I said I was looking for the coconut mango ice cream.

He said he could pack it for me but I seriously didn't know how much I wanted and admitted that I was just planning on buying them out! He said he could pack some for me and I brain freezed as I was calculating how much I could carry and walk with for 10-15 minutes to get home.

One of the staff asked me how many I wanted.  I WANTED 20, but despondently and responsibly said 4 pints.  THAT'S STILL RESPONSIBLE!  I think I sounded really depressed when I said it when I think back on, but YEAAAAHH!  It's as good as I remember!
author: Sara P.

description:
This place is great, I recommend getting a flight of flavors because they always have new delicious flavors!

They once had a PB n J flavor which was my absolute favorite, but now they have all new tasty flavors.

I love their mint chip!

Others I love - peanut butter chocolate, strawberry balsamic, and horchata!

Will come again, especially for the lovely smell of fresh waffles! Yum!
author: Kimia M.

description: It's a cute place. However the prices are pretty high for ice cream that's not as flavorful as others I've tried. It's a cute vibe in the store and a great date spot. There's some interesting flavors they have daily which I assume rotate through.
author: Kalani R.

description: This place is always a treat whenever I'm in the area. Flavors are always on point, and their ice creams are just the way I like them: creamy and solid. My advice is to check their website and social media pages for their current list of flavors. The employees are also nice enough to let you sample before buying!
author: Connie X.

description:
I ordered the chocolate peanut butter fudge ice cream in a cone! It was super delicious and the flavors were even! It wasn't too much or little of any of the chocolate and peanut butter. The cone was AMAZING, it tasted like a Cinnabon! At least to me haha! 
The place itself is really cute. I love the paintings on the walls! 
5 stars! Xo
author: Kristi A.

description: This is one of the highlights of my family's San Francisco trip. Though we have only spent a few days here, the incredible city has not failed to amaze my family and the culinary wonders that the city brings are just another contributing factor to my family's love of the city. This place has wonderful icecream, creative flavors, and a lovely atmosphere and staff. I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Isabella D.

description: Peanut butter chocolate fudge....you'll thank me later. that is all I have to say in my review.
author: Tashi. O.

description:
Nice spot to catch up w friends, and interesting ice home made ice cream. Parking is meh, it's honestly okay during the daytime on weekdays but pretty bad on weekends. 

My friend who brought me here really loves this place and I can see why! I wanted to try all the flavors because he loved this place so much, but unfortunately they didn't have his and everyone's fav, the mint chip.

But we shared the flight which is five diff flavors in (what looks like) shot cups. The flavors we chose included honey lemon rosemary, mango sorbet, chocolate sorbet, peanut butter and chocolate fudge and salted caramel. Also comes w a side of waffle chips to eat w/ the ice cream. 

My favs in order was the peanut butter + chocolate fudge (soo flavorful), honey lemon rosemary (very fragrant and unique) and mango sorbet. The others were good too but these are the ones I'd get again!
author: Melanie T.

description:
My type of flights: ice cream flights.

It's about $12 for 5 flavors, and it's a pretty great value if there's at least one other person in your party. A couple of flavors are seasonal and rotate out, but one of the main staples was their fresh mint - mint is actually one of my favorite flavors (yes, the super processed green colored one), but Hometown make it vibrant and refreshing.

Most of the other flavors were not really up my alley, but I suppose that's the fun in getting a flight. Hopefully other people in your party are keen to finish the ones you don't like!
author: Jerry C.

description:
This time I had a much better experience with the flavors. I got tea time, chocolate peanut butter, carrot cake, basil, and clementine sorbet. My favorites were the tea time and and carrot cake. The clementine was really good too but it was kinda strange to eat it with all the other creamy flavors.

Cons: they take forever to scoop flights because they're super precise on not giving you too much for each scoop -_-
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Omg... delicious ice cream! You can even try their "smidge" sized ice cream which sometimes I just want a taste and not a whole scoop.  Even on a rainy day this place was crowded. This place doesn't really have your everyday flavors. Their flavors are very unique, and worth trying, amd they even make their own waffle cones right in front of you. 

I decided to try their Thai ice cream,  Khao Niao Ma Muang. It was like eating the Thai dessert that has the sweet sticky rice with mango. It was delicious,  and I regret not getting a larger size. I also tried their carrot cake ice cream,  which tasted like carrot cake.  I will definitely come back to this place.
author: Monica K.

description:
Super cute little ice cream shop. The decor was pretty but not try-hard like some places in SF can be. Minimalistic but in a good way. 

Service was excellent. We were given tastes before we made a final selection and she didn't rush us at all. Very nice young girl working. I'm sure they were busy all day as it was a Saturday and she was ready to leave but they didn't rush us out despite arriving close to closing time, which I really appreciated. 

The bench seats were surprisingly very comfy. 

Ice cream flavors were unique but not too out there. My husband had the Sufganiyot, which is described as a Hanukkah jelly donut. It was really tasty! He also had the Coquito which is described as a Puerto Rican Eggnog. It tasted like Cinnamon Toast Crunch cereal to me :) I had the Crescent City Bread Pudding flavor. It was exactly what I was hoping for. Something more mildly flavored, but nice & creamy. The waffle cones also had a cereal taste, very sugary. 

Grabbed a chocolate chip cookie for a midnight snack after our 2 hour drive home. It was perfect as far as chocolate chip cookies go. Tasted homemade, soft and chewy.
author: Ashley J.

description:
After a quick lunch, this was the first place that my brother and wife brought us to when my fiance and I visited them last week in San Francisco. I looooved their housemade ice creams, and also loved the option of an ice cream flight! My conversation with the person behind the bar literally went like this:

Me: "Can I try the cantaloupe?"
*He gives me sample of the cantaloupe flavor*
Me: "Oh my god... that tastes EXACTLY like cantaloupe!"

Me: "Can I try the banana bread?"
*He gives me sample of the banana bread flavor*
Me: "Oh my god... that tastes EXACTLY like banana bread!"

... aaaand et cetera for ALL the flavors. Quite fortunately for me, he was quite patient, amused, and also friendly and chatty.

With that being said, my favorite was definitely Tea Time on the Thames, which is an earl grey tea and lavender flavor. I loved the floral notes in this flavor.

Will definitely be coming back the next time I'm in town.
author: Amy W.

description:
Their ice cream is made in house and is some of the best I've ever tasted. They had both traditional and seasonal flavors making it hard to choose. Though I guess if it gets too tough you can always go for a flight of ice cream. Yep you read that right! 
I was being sensible so opted for 2 scoops in a cup but it's the little touches like them asking which flavor they should put at the top and which at the bottom which set them apart for me. 
Go here! You won't be disappointed.
author: Parvinder H.

description: After dinner, we decided to stop by here for ice cream to end the meal. The shop has a couple tables, but really not much room to stay and finish your ice cream. At first glance, we were going to go to for the ice cream flight until we realized how limited the flavors were. And honestly, none of the flavors really stood out to us, but one. Yep, we like our basic and plain vanilla ice cream. We each got a single scoop Madagascar Vanilla ice cream in a cone ($3.95). The ice cream was yummy, but on the pricey-end and with limited flavors, so eh.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
The flight is a great option if you want to try a variety of the flavors offered here although it may seem pricey. I think the flight is definitely worth it if you share it with others. I split the flight between 3 friends so the cost was less for each of us while still getting a decent amount of ice cream to eat! 

The fresh mint tasted like a spring roll - it was good but a bit overpowering the more you eat it. 
Madagascar vanilla is standard, never disappoints. 
The hibiscus lime was a rotational flavor but it was very unique and good! 
Tea time on the Thames which is an earl grey flavor, was good and my favorite out of the 5 flavors.
Strawberry balsamic was really good as well. 

I'm not TOO picky when it comes to ice cream, but from other reviews I do agree that the ice cream here is more icy than I'm used to. While the flavors are good, it would definitely stand out more if the texture was more creamy.
author: Alyssa G.

description: This has to be the freshest icecream I've had! They have some writing on the wall that promotes from farm to table. We had a mint icecream that tasted like a mint leaf blessed your tastebuds. Seriously, it was unreal. You taste all the raw ingredients and you may never look at icecream the same way again. You WILL NOT regret stopping by!
author: Rick H.

description:
Best ice cream in San Francisco is a tie:
Hometown Creamery and Salt & Straw.

But since Salt & Straw is a Portland-based transplant, Hometown Creamery... wins! Here's the weird thing. The first time I went there, I was like, eh. Then, I went there again, and was like, Whoa. And then again, Whoa. They've found their stride.

Now, I love Bi-Rite's Salted Caramel, Marco Polo's Taro, Three Twin's Cardamom, Polly Ann's Jasmine Tea, S&S's Tres Leche, and Smitten's Chocolate Tcho, but there's something about the freshness of Hometown Creamery's ice cream that truly transcends every single one of these. It must be the small-batches + an inventiveness not like the flavor-bombs at S&S, but far more simple, and real. 

Like Alice Waters said, someone open an ice cream shop that is Northern California, please. And God said, okay, Hometown Creamery. Because God listens deeply to Alice Waters. This is why we have $16 avocado toast. The New-American Northern California aesthetic doesn't always work out, but that's okay. It worked out here, for the benefit of San Francisco. But I digress...

The fresh mint chip, is the best mint chip by far. Yes, it takes a moment to re-adjust. We're like the animal in the chemical mint-chip cage, that when it sees the light, stays inside its fake-green weird preferences. But then, once you get past the crap-chocolate chip bars, and into the light where the fresh mint grows, you'll never want to go back. Would it be pretentious to say... it's refined? 

Friends of mine who are healthy and dairy-free swear by the dark chocolate sorbet. Yes, but in my own lactose-intolerant denial, I will go for a flight of everything dairy. Plus, a coffee with cream. The peanut butter fudge always ends up as one of the five. They're kind of small scoops. I go with people, I swear. I share... sometimes. 

I heard they make an ice cream called La Vie en Rose, which I know would make me cry delicate pink rose petal tears of happiness. Please, for the love of San Francisco, would you make another single batch? :* 

...and let a girl know? ;)
author: Maria A.

description: Best of the best ice cream and service can be found here! Everything is made fresh on site! My friend and I visited on a week day when the lines weren't so crazy and got a tour of the facilities from co-owner Saadi. Rather than a bunch of fad flavors, they have a unique assortment of flavors with global inspirations. My friend and I got the baklava flavor and the centeotl tribute, inspired mesoamerican flavors of sweet corn and spicy Chile guajillo caramel! Whenever I am back in San Francisco, I will be stopping here again for sure.
author: Courtney W.

description:
The flight is a must-try, but make sure to sample and choose your flavors carefully! There's a limited assortment (around 8 flavors) to make decision-making easier, but I do wish they offered a more expansive selection.

I made the mistake of not trying the ones I ordered and ended up disappointed with 3 of the 5 scoops. The Rosemary, Cafe au lait, and Basil were some of their more unique flavors, but turned out to be more watery than creamy. Surprisingly, what I enjoyed most was their more traditional flavors. The PB/chocolate was decadent and creamy, and the Chocolate sorbet was rich without being excessively sweet.

What I appreciated was the decor/service here. Staff are friendly and helpful despite how hectic everything is, and they also gave us a bonus cup of crushed waffle cone to go with our flight! Loved the paintings of SF neighborhoods adorning the walls as well.
author: Amy C.

description:
What a cool little place! With delicious ice cream and a great vibe!! 

We came in today - Sunday - shortly after they opened. I had an ice cream flight, hubby had the carrot cake ice cream and our friend had a chocolate milkshake. 

The carrot cake flavour was great! My flight consisted of vanilla, mango sorbet, honey lemon rosemary, black sesame and cantuccini (can't remember what flavours now but it's good). I loved them all, full of flavour, especially the honey lemon rosemary and mango. Both of them very refreshing.
author: Rowena B.

description:
While I definitely love how more and more premium ice cream shops have been opening in SF over the years, it's kind of a bummer how so many of them aren't exactly in the most convenient parts of town.  The Mission, Tenderloin, Potrero Hill, Hayes Valley...I may be willing to drive for a tasty scoop or two, but dang, it'd sure be nice if parking was relatively easy once I arrived!  Thank goodness for Hometown Creamery!

Now, searching for parking around 9th Ave isn't exactly a field trip, but it's certainly not as bad here as other parts of the city.  Admittedly, I'm also in the neighborhood pretty often, so it's convenient to drop in on a whim, but I'd still come by even if I wasn't.  Focusing on small batch ice cream made in house, their flavors are pretty unique and always taste really fresh!

On any given night, including the eight offered on my most recent visit, they offer a wide range of creations, from the classic (Mint Chip, Chocolate Sorbet) to the creative (Navajo Squash Blossom and Taysia's Thanksgiving Special).  After sampling a couple of them, I opted to go with one of the more frequent offerings they rotate in - PEANUT BUTTER CHOCOLATE FUDGE ($3.95, single scoop).

Although it doesn't look nearly the same, I thought this tasted very similar to the version I used to get as a kid from Baskin-Robbins.  Even without the giant chunks of peanut butter (which I LOVED), this one was rich, had a nice balance of flavors, and didn't seem overly sweet or sugary.  As for the texture, I liked how it wasn't very icy and had a nice creaminess to it, though my friend thought hers could've been creamier.

Compared to the likes of Bi-Rite, Humphrey Slocombe, or Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous, it'd be fair to say that Hometown Creamery falls just a bit short.  However, they're still pretty solid in their own right and worth a trip for any ice cream lover (especially their flight of ice cream!).  I actually first came here on a date, but made a point of coming back so that I could try something else (and to get a photo, since I couldn't the first time around...).

Considering how good the ice cream is and how easy it is to come by, I'll definitely be back...and probably more often than I should!
author: Mike L.

description:
Ice cream sampler! 

Mainly because it's totally IG worthy (yes, I'm one of those...LOL) but the ice cream itself was delicious! My friend and I even enjoyed the vegan ones!

Friendly service! It was just in the store but the person working was willing to answer all our questions and let us sample everything.
author: Noelle H.

description: This ice cream shop had some great unique flavors which was what drew us in. I ordered the caipirinha sorbet and my friends ordered the apple and honey, horchata and peanut butter ice creams. All had a great flavor; however, the texture was more icy than I would like. I prefer a much creamier ice cream but this was not the case.
author: Angela M.

description: I had such high hopes for this ice cream parlor and was sadly let down. I had Strawberry Balsamic and Cream of the Crop (sweet corn) in a cone with salted caramel sauce topping. The scoops were not only tiny but the cone was also one of the smallest I've ever gotten at an ice cream shop. The texture of the ice cream was weirdly icy, not creamy - and I couldn't detect any hint of balsamic in the Strawberry Balsamic (Bi-Rite's balsamic strawberry is far superior IMHO). On top of everything, the caramel sauce that I paid extra for was just a tiny drizzle. I appreciate their back story and their farm-to-cone philosophy, but I just didn't really like the texture or flavors.
author: Jen L.

description: I am spoiled with ice cream from Salt and Straw, Smitten, Humphrey Schlombe, even three twins I like. This just didn't stand up to other choices in the city. It reminded me of ice cream 20 years ago- Baskin's and Robbins and Dreyers. Very basic despite unique flavors. It's it decadent, rich or creamy. Sorry to say but it wasn't good for me.
author: Piper W.

description:
